pageData.text: Owls disgorge pellets containing the indigestible parts of their prey. Wildlife biologists routinely collect and examine <button class=glossary-text>owl pellets</button> to determine the species, populations, proportions, and seasonal variations of the owls’ prey. Moreover, they can even get a quick assessment of the small mammal population residing in a given area. This activity is intended to take two weeks and will require you to share and aggregate data collected by others in your class.

pageData.title: Needed but not supplied:
text: Blank white paper
Soap and water
A 10% bleach solution for sanitizing your work space
Paper towels

pageData.title: Time Requirements
pageData.altText:
Preparation – 5 minutes
Activity 1: Owl Pellet Investigation – 60 minutes
Activity 2: Owl Pellet Investigation Results – 30 minutes

text: Identify bones of an owl’s prey using a dichotomous key.
Communicate data about the number and types of prey found and hypothesize about which biome the pellet was collected in.
Compare the diets of owls from different <button class=glossary-text>biomes</button>.
Infer the impact of an individual species on a community.
Define the different <button class=glossary-text>trophic levels</button> and assign predators and prey to the appropriate levels.
Describe how an owl pellet is produced and what its contents reveal about the predator and its prey.

pageData.subTitle: Hazard pictograms

pageData.text: In Minamata, Japan in the 1950s, high levels of mercury (a heavy metal neurotoxin) were secretly released into the surrounding bay. People first noticed something was wrong when the cats of the area began “dancing” or having spasmodic, jerky movements as mercury in their systems began to interfere with nerve signaling. Inexplicably, people began to experience similar symptoms. The mercury level in the water was not high enough to cause toxicity on its own and people who swam in or drank from the water were unharmed.

It was the food web and predation patterns of the area that were magnifying the effects of the mercury.  Smaller organisms, like phyto- and zooplankton, absorbed the mercury from the water. This <button class=glossary-text>trophic level</button> absorbed relatively small amounts of mercury and were unharmed; however, most organisms are unable to rid their bodies of mercury, so it becomes stored. When small fish ate the plankton, they <button class=glossary-text>ingested</button> the stored mercury, concentrating and storing it in their own tissues. They were then eaten by large fish, resulting in their having high concentrations of mercury. When the cats and humans ate these large fish, the mercury accumulated in their bodies as well, causing mercury toxicity.

pageData.altText: Fish being sold at market for human consumption
pageData.desc: Fish being sold at market for human consumption

pageData.text: One of the most important interactions within a community is predator-prey interaction in which one organism kills and consumes the other. The effects on the prey are immediate and lasting, killing both the individual and its potential future contribution to the population in the form of offspring. The impact on the prey’s population, however, is potentially beneficial. Predation is rarely completely random. Frequently the individuals that are preyed upon are those that are easier to catch because they are inherently weaker and slower, lack behaviors that increase their chance of survival, or are weakened by disease or hunger. Thus, not only are slower, weaker individuals more likely to be removed from the population, but those who are less adept at finding food or more susceptible to disease are also more likely to be eliminated.

pageData.subTitle: Trophic Transfer
pageData.text: Scientists group organisms into <button class=glossary-text>trophic levels</button> according to their primary source of energy. There are three basic types of organisms: <button class=glossary-text>producers</button>, <button class=glossary-text>consumers</button>, and <button class=glossary-text>decomposers</button>.

• Producers convert non-organic energy (usually from the sun) into chemical energy.
  • Consumers are broken down into primary (1°) consumers and secondary (2°) consumers based on whether their main source of energy comes from producers (primary consumers) or other consumers (secondary consumers).
  • Decomposers, or detritivores, feed upon the dead matter of producers, consumers, and other decomposers.

No energy transfer is 100% efficient. When a consumer ingests an organism, only a fraction of the energy is incorporated into the tissue, or <button class=glossary-text>assimilated</button>, into the consumer. Assimilation is defined as the difference between the amount <button class=glossary-text>ingested</button> and the amount of energy <button class=glossary-text>excreted</button> in the form of urine and feces.

Some of the assimilated energy is used for metabolic processes, and is ultimately lost to the organism in the form of heat. The rest of the assimilated energy becomes the of the consumer. The is the percentage of the assimilated energy that becomes new biomass. Biomass is the amount of organic matter in a system.

This loss of energy results in a corresponding decrease in at each . Ecologists frequently use 10% between trophic levels as a “rule of thumb.” In most terrestrial environments this creates a trophic pyramid (see Figure 1), where the amount of biomass is greatest in the lower trophic levels and each subsequent trophic level has substantially less biomass than the previous one.

pageData.altText: Figure 1: Biomass pyramid showing producers with the largest biomass at the bottom, primary consumers above, and the smallest biomass of predators at the top.

pageData.text: TrophicWeb.jpg by Thompsma is available under Creative Commons Attribution Generic 3.0 Unreported License at https://commons.wikimedia.org/wiki/File:TrophicWeb.jpg

pageData.subTitle: Food Webs
pageData.text: So far we have talked about energy transfer as if it is a linear transition from one group of organisms to another; however, reality is much more complex. The diet of the barn owl is made up primarily of voles and mice (1° ), shrews (2° consumers), and rats (2° consumers and detritivores). Predators often exhibit preferences for certain types of prey that are usually determined by their ease of capture and nutritive value. These factors change in different locations and at different times of the year.

Linear food chains are inherently unstable as a disruption to any member of the community has a profound effect on all populations within the chain. A complex food web (see Figure 2), where a disruption in only one or two populations can be compensated for by several other populations, results in a more stable community. In the illustrated food web, algae, diatoms, and water plants feed tadpoles, water snails, mayfly nymphs, daphnia, hydra, annelid worms, and flatworms, which in turn, feed diving beetles, small fish, bladderwort, dragon fly nymphs, and water boatman. Large fish eat the small fish and the dragonfly nymphs. Consider what happens when the mayfly nymph is removed from the food web. The algae upon which they feed may experience an increase in growth, but that will quickly be transferred to the tadpoles and daphnia. More daphnia in the system will replace the need for the mayfly nymph in the diet of the small fish. In a more linear food chain, that consisted of only algae, mayflies and small fish, for example, removing the mayflies would have a catastrophic impact on the small fish population as their only food source would be eliminated.

pageData.altText: Figure 2: pond food web showing a complex food web

pageData.subTitle: Barn Owls
pageData.text: Barn owls prefer quiet, secluded forest edges near open grasslands where they can feed on rodents, small birds, and other small mammals, such as rabbits. Such a diet compels them to settle into barns and silos, where farmers welcome their assistance in controlling the mice and rats that feed on their harvests.

Owls usually swallow their prey whole. However, owls differ from other species of birds because they do not have a , the baglike organ used to store food after it has been swallowed so that it can be digested later. In owls, food passes directly from the mouth to the . The gizzard is an organ that uses digestive fluids and bits of sand and gravel to grind and dissolve all of the usable tissue from the prey.

The types of tissue that can be dissolved by an owl’s digestive system include muscle, fat, skin, and internal organs. These tissues are broken down into a variety of nutritional substances by the owl’s gizzard and intestines. Some of these tissues (e.g., fur and bones) cannot be digested.

This material, along with other waste collected throughout the body, is ejected from the <button class=glossary-text>vent</button>, which is a combination of reproductive opening and excretory opening in birds. The pasty white excrement is known as urea. It is very rich in nitrogen and similar to urine in mammals, only thicker. Indigestible material left in the gizzard such as teeth, skulls, claws, and feathers are too dangerous to pass through the rest of the owl’s digestive tract. To safely excrete this material, the owl’s gizzard compacts it into a tight pellet that the owl regurgitates. The regurgitated pellets are known as <button class=glossary-text>owl pellets</button>.

An owl pellet generally reaches its final form a few hours after the owl has eaten. However, the pellet is not usually ejected immediately after it is formed. Owls can store a pellet in a structure known as the <button class=glossary-text>proventriculus</button> for as long as 20 hours before disgorging it. Since the stored pellet partially blocks the entrance to the digestive system, it must be ejected before the  owl can eat again. Owls typically produce 1 to 3 pellets per day.

The actual process of regurgitating a pellet lasts from a few seconds to several minutes. The pellet is forced out by spasms of the owl’s esophagus that make the owl look like it is coughing painfully. However, it is not hurt by the process because the pellet remains soft and moist until it leaves the owl’s body.

pageData.question: Why must an owl eject the pellet before it can eat again?

options.text: It blocks the entrance to the digestive system.
Regurgitating a pellet takes a long time.
Prey bones take up to 20 hours to breakdown.
It can only be stored in the crop for a short period of time.

feedbackData.title: Feedback
feedbackData.text: Since the stored pellet partially blocks the entrance to the digestive system, it must be ejected before the owl can eat again.

pageData.question: Which of the following statements about owl digestion is true?

options.text: Owls expel prey material, such as skulls, when they eject owl pellets.
Owls store their food in a crop before passing it to the gizzard.
Owls have a diet made up of only 1° consumers.
Owls take 20 hours to digest one meal.
Owls use their gizzards to absorb fats and nutrients from their food.

feedbackData.title: Feedback
feedbackData.text: Owls expel prey material (teeth, skulls, claws, feathers, etc.) in their ejected owl pellets.

These factors change in different locations and at different times of the year. Owls usually swallow their prey whole: food passes directly from the mouth to the gizzard. The gizzard is an organ that uses digestive fluids and bits of sand and gravel to grind and dissolve all the usable tissue from the prey. Indigestible material left in the gizzard such as teeth, skulls, claws, and feathers are too dangerous to pass through the rest of the owl’s digestive tract. To safely excrete this material, the owl’s gizzard compacts it into a tight pellet, an owl pellet, that the owl regurgitates. Since the stored pellet partially blocks the entrance to the digestive system, it must be ejected before the owl can eat again. Owls typically produce 1 to 3 pellets per day.

hintData.body: The diet of the barn owl is made up primarily of voles and mice (1° consumers), shrews (2° consumers), and rats (2° consumers and detritivores). These factors change in different locations and at different times of the year. Owls usually swallow their prey whole: food passes directly from the mouth to the gizzard. The gizzard is an organ that uses digestive fluids and bits of sand and gravel to grind and dissolve all the usable tissue from the prey. Indigestible material left in the gizzard such as teeth, skulls, claws, and feathers are too dangerous to pass through the rest of the owl’s digestive tract. To safely excrete this material, the owl’s gizzard compacts it into a tight pellet, an owl pellet, that the owl regurgitates. Since the stored pellet partially blocks the entrance to the digestive system, it must be ejected before the owl can eat again. Owls typically produce 1 to 3 pellets per day.

pageData.text: Through careful examination of the pellet’s contents, researchers can discover quite a bit about an owl’s lifestyle and the community in which it lives. Since most of the prey’s bones are not actually broken during the attack and the subsequent digestion process, they can be readily identified in the pellet. Most pellets include a skull(s), which can be used to identify the prey. It can be challenging to distinguish all the features and characteristics of a type of organism; however, a dichotomous key can be used to facilitate this process. A dichotomous key is a tool for identifying items based on a series of choices between pairs of descriptors that refer to the organism under investigation. With each choice, the user is directed to another choice, ultimately leading to one that definitively identifies the organism.

In this lab, you will examine the contents of two . Through studying the contents of the owl pellets, you may observe nocturnal or daytime eating, seasonal, and regional differences. These different regions occupy different (see Figure 3). Biomes are defined primarily by their temperatures and humidity. Regions of similar temperature and humidity tend to support similar ecosystems (see ). Based on the bones you find in your pellet, you will hypothesize which biome the owl pellet was collected in and the owl species might be. You will share your data with your classmates and use it to extrapolate the likely numbers and types of prey consumed by an individual owl in each of the regions. You will hypothesize a potential food web and use it to discuss differences in the communities represented.

pageData.altText: Figure 3: Map of biomes in North America, including tundra, moist coniferous forest, northern coniferous forest, grassland, chaparral, eastern deciduous forest, desert, and tropical forest.

options.text: by their average amount of sun and daylight
by what animals are found there
by the hemispheres in which they are found

feedbackData.title: Feedback
feedbackData.text: Biomes are defined primarily by their temperatures and humidity.

pageData.question: Which of the following will you most likely use as evidence to support your hypotheses about the origins of your owl pellets?

options.text: The identity of the prey bones in the owl pellets, which prey are found in certain biomes.
The size of the owl pellets, which suggests the average annual temperature of the biome.
The smell of the owl pellets, which suggests the primary vegetation of the biome.
The number of prey species in the owl pellets, which suggests the total area of the biome.
The density of the owl pellets, which suggests the annual precipitation of the biome.

pageData.altText: A map describing the procedural workflow for this investigation. In Activity 1, you will remove all of the bones from an owl pellet. You will then use the skulls that you find to identify the organisms in the pellet. Next, examine the second pellet following the same procedure. In Activity 2, you will compile the data with your class or group. Then you will calculate the percent of each type of organism present in each pellet. Finally, you will use the data to hypothesize about the region of origin for the pellet.

pageData.text: Reorder Information: Replacement supplies for Predator/Prey Interactions (item number 580205) can be ordered from Carolina Biological Supply Company. Call: 866.332.4478 to order.
Wear your safety goggles, lab apron, and gloves at all times while conducting this investigation.

pageData.desc: goggles symbol, gloves symbol, apron symbol
pageData.altText: goggles symbol, gloves symbol, apron symbol

pageData.text: Read all instructions for this laboratory activity before beginning. Follow the instructions closely and observe established laboratory safety practices, including the use of appropriate personal protective equipment.

<button class=glossary-text>Owl pellets</button> contain the remains of small animals that the owl has <button class=glossary-text>ingested</button> and can be a source of bacterial contamination. Carolina’s individually wrapped owl pellets are heat sterilized at 250 ºF for 4 hours to render microbes nonviable, including salmonella strains. We do not treat them with chemicals. Keep them wrapped until use to prevent insect infestations or contamination.
Complete dissection activities in one day. Once finished, promptly dispose of the owl pellets and all disposable materials used in the activity.
Handle owl pellets, even sterilized ones, as though they could be a source of bacterial or viral contamination.

Owl pellets should not be dissected in areas where food is consumed. Cover your work space with the dissection pad provided. Also use the disposable tray provided for dissection of the pellets, and dispose of it promptly upon completion of the activity.

Use gloves and wash hands before and immediately after the activity. After removing and disposing of gloves, wash your hands with  soap and warm water by rubbing them into a lather for at least 20 seconds before rinsing. Do not use a waterless hand sanitizer that does not have an alcohol content of at least 70%.

Chlorine bleach is a corrosive material. Chlorine bleach can cause serious eye damage. Use these materials near a source of running water that can be used as a safety eyewash or safety shower if any corrosive material comes in contact with skin or eyes. Do not use bleach in an area without proper ventilation, such as an open window or a bathroom with a fan. Disinfect the work area with a 10% bleach solution (one part bleach to nine parts tap water) before starting the investigation. Immediately after the dissection  activity, wash and sanitize work surfaces using 10% household bleach solution. Use disposable paper towels and throw them away. Do not use sponges or rags that might hold and spread bacteria or viruses. Beware: chlorine bleach is corrosive and irritating to the skin and may damage clothing.

<span class='bodyParaLineBreak'>Do not eat, drink, or chew gum while performing this activity. Wash your hands with soap and water before and after performing the activity. Keep pets and children away from lab materials and equipment.

pageData.title: Pre-Lab Assessment Introduction
pageData.text: Directions: Complete this pre-lab assessment to continue to the rest of the investigation. You will need a score of 100% to pass the assessment. This assessment can be attempted as many times as necessary to achieve a passing score. You may return to the pre-lab sections to study before each attempt.For each question, select your response and then click Submit to see how you did. Click Next to continue to the next question. A final results page will appear upon completion of this assessment with your overall performance.

In Activity 1, you will examine 2 <button class=glossary-text>owl pellets</button> and remove any bones you find. You will then use the dichotomous key in Table 2 to identify any skulls you find. You will record how many of each type of organism the owl consumed based on this skull data.

Place the first owl pellet on the tray. Using your fingers, probe, or forceps, break off a small chunk of the pellet. Be gentle and do not push the probe, or forceps, any further into the pellet than necessary. Remember, the bones you are looking for are small and easily broken.
Carefully tear the pellet apart and set aside any bones that you find within it on the owl pellet mat.
Compare the bones you found with the ones pictured on the bone charts (Figure 4 and Table 2).

tableData.text: Canines present between incisors and molars; little to no gap
Long pair of incisors on upper and lower jaw; gap between incisors and molars
Zygomatic arch incomplete; tips of teeth reddish
Skull flat and broad; molars flat topped and acutely angled; may appear to be a single tooth
Skull rounded; molars have rounded cusps
Upper incisor notched at tip; skull less than 32 mm
No notch in upper incisor; skull more than 32 mm

pageData.text: Identify as many bones as possible.
If your instructor wants you to examine differences in the prey skeletal anatomy, organize the bones by placing them according to the corresponding bone chart (Table 2).
Repeat this process until you have completely dissected the pellet and removed all of the bones.

The prey eaten are recorded according to the number of skulls found in the pellet. Identify each of the skulls found using the dichotomous key provided (Figure 4 and Table 2), and record your findings in Data Table 1.
Based on the number of skulls you have identified, use Table 3 to form a hypothesis about the region where the owl pellet was collected and record it in Data Table 1.

pageData.text: *Data based on reports from the Audubon Society and aggregated data by Carolina Biological Supply Company (http://www.carolina.com/teacher-resources/Interactive/owl-pellet-interactive-database/tr10836.tr?intid=10786_700_b_interactiveowldatabase).

To use the key, start at number 1 and decide if the specimen at hand has the first characteristic or the second. If it has the first characteristic (the skull has a beak), then it is a bird and classification is complete. If the skull has teeth, on the other hand, move to the second pair of characteristics. Continue until the skull is identified. You may need to measure the incisor with a ruler to determine if the specimen is a rat or a mouse.
Repeat Steps 2–9 with your second owl pellet.
In Activity 2, you will use the data collected in Activity 1 to calculate the percentage of the owl diet that each organism makes up and hypothesize where each pellet was collected.

Share your data with the class. Compile everyone’s data into Data Table 2 to determine the total for each type of organism in the , what the owl is, and what region each pellet is hypothesized to be from.

Calculate the percentage each prey contributes to the diet of owls in each region by dividing the total number of each prey counted in your class by the total number of prey organisms counted. Record this data in Data Table 2.
Based on the percentage of each organism you identified, hypothesize which region the pellet was collected in. Record your observations in Data Table 2.
Refer to your instructor’s directions for further analysis options.

Wash and sanitize work surfaces immediately after the dissection activity according to the Safety instructions.

Conduct a literature/internet search to determine the food choices of the prey found in your owl pellets.

data.title: Assimilated
data.content: Describes the energy from food that is incorporated in to the tissue of the consumer

data.title: Biomass
data.content: The amount of organic matter in a system

data.title: Biomes
data.content: Regions of Earth defined by their temperature and humidity

data.title: Consumer
data.content: An organism that preys on other organisms

data.title: Crop
data.content: The bag-like organ in birds used to store food after it has been swallowed

data.title: Decomposer
data.content: An organism, such as a bacterium or fungus, that decomposes organic material

data.title: Excreted
data.content: Expelled from the body as waste

data.title: Gizzard
data.content: The organ in birds that uses digestive fluids and bits of sand and gravel to grind and dissolve useable tissue from consumed prey

data.title: Ingested
data.content: Taken into the body as food by swallowing or absorption

data.title: Owl pellets
data.content: Tightly packed material too dangerous to go through the digestive tract and is regurgitated by the owl

data.title: Producer
data.content: An autotrophic organism that is a source of biomass and can be consumed by other organisms; found in the first trophic level

data.title: Production efficiency
data.content: The precentage of assimilated enrgy that becomes new biomass

data.title: Proventriculus
data.content: The narrow glandular first region of a bird's stomach between the crop and the gizzard

data.title: Trophic level
data.content: The group of organisms within an ecosystem that occupy the same level in a food chain

data.title: Vent
data.content: A reproductive and excretory opening in birds
